questions.neutral: Do the streets feel heavier today?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Heavy, yes. People keep to themselves lately.
I spend time with my typewriter when things are unsettled.
Hard to focus on repairs with all these new notices at my door.
Everyone wants something on paper now.
There’s a tension in the air since ration rules shifted.
I’ve been restoring old typewriters. Simple, reliable.
Neighbors knocking for paperwork more often these days.
My hobby became a necessity, not just a pastime.
It’s not as peaceful as it used to be.
The streets do feel heavier, especially near the queues.
Used to spend quiet hours repairing my Remington typewriter.
Now, neighbors want me to type forms for the new Congress.
People trust ink over digital signatures these days.
Last week I only managed half a repair before more paperwork.
The city’s uncertainty creeps into every corner, even old hobbies.
Yes, the weight is different, though familiar if you’ve lived here long enough.
I restore antique typewriters. The rhythm keeps me steady.
With all these new Congress lists, typing became unofficial work.
Old typewriters are in demand—seems irony isn’t lost here.
They ask for handwritten and typed lists, afraid of digital tracking.
Last time, I missed an entire afternoon of repairs for neighborhood forms.
Strange how a hobby becomes a lifeline when systems falter.
The city sits differently now, doesn’t it? Almost like 2021, only quieter.
I’ve kept to restoring typewriters for decades—Remingtons, Royals, anything mechanical.
It’s half therapy, half rebellion: I don’t trust screens anymore.
Since the Congress took over, neighbors line up for documents, not just repairs.
Last week, I spent hours typing ration rosters when the digital system failed.
Suddenly every form needs real ink, real signatures—feels like before Halden.
I even dug out my old Council stamp, not that it means much now.
My workshop is half refuge, half community desk. Funny how things change.
hobby_answer: Nothing serious. Just dust and jammed keys again.
People have been asking to borrow it lately—never happened before.
Nowadays, even a typewriter draws attention, it seems.
Hard to keep private routines when schedules keep changing.
. . . times aren’t what they were.
Minor trouble. The carriage sticks, but I manage.
Strange, since blackout, more neighbors notice my old machines.
Folk knock for 'typed' forms—the computer lists are all mixed up now.
I keep my own work locked away, just in case.
Hard to say who’s asking for what motive these days.
Best to stay careful. No such thing as a harmless favor.
No more than usual, just worn springs and ribbon, you know.
After the blackout and the new Congress rules, everything’s manual again.
Neighbors suddenly want signs, lists, forms—old paper methods.
Funny how distrust in the screens brought folks to my door.
Lost a few good hours last week drafting neighborhood rosters.
Reminds me why I keep spare ribbons.
Typewriters don’t leak data, at least.
Yes, the Remington needed its third spring replaced—same every few months.
Since those new Congress leaders took over, chaos—everyone’s after hand-typed forms.
I used to mend machines just for myself, now it’s for the whole floor.
After the blackout, my flat became an unofficial paperwork post.
Favors traded for a typed notice—strange economics these days.
I keep a journal about all this, in cursive, behind a lock.
People trust paper now, not portals.
At least the old skills keep me useful.
It’s the spacebar this time—had to salvage a spring from my father’s Olivetti.
Back in my Council days, typewriters were for nostalgia. Now, my neighbors queue for proof of address.
Blackout broke more than the lights. Screen distrust is so sharp, they’d rather a stamped sheet.
Last week, I spent hours typing ration rosters, dodging the new ‘coordinator’s’ eyes.
I haven’t finished my own repairs in ages—service trumps solitude now.
Funny, those forms I typed got handed out by the new Congress leaders. Same faces, new paperwork.
I keep two journals now—one for public eyes, one truth in the safe.
Strange power, these old machines, when governance fails.
We lived through transitions before, but never like this.
